questions.text: A previously healthy 48-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 3-week history of progressively worsening jaundice, generalized itching, and epigastric discomfort. He also has nausea and loss of appetite. His stools have looked like clay for the past week. He has returned from a vacation in Thailand one week ago, where he got a new tattoo. He is sexually active with multiple partners and does not use protection. His vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows jaundice and scleral icterus. Superficial excoriations are seen on all limbs. Abdominal examination shows no abnormalities. Serum studies show a fasting glucose level of 198 mg/dL, total bilirubin concentration of 10.6 mg/dL, direct bilirubin concentration of 9.8 mg/dl, and alkaline phosphatase activity of 450 U/L. Abdominal ultrasonography shows dilation of the biliary and pancreatic ducts and a 3-cm hypoechoic solid mass with irregular margins in the head of the pancreas. An elevation of which of the following serum findings is most specific for this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Although an elevated CA 125 is present in about half the cases of pancreatic cancer, it is both less sensitive and less specific than another tumor marker that also has prognostic value in the treatment of pancreatic cancer. Instead, an elevated CA 125 is especially sensitive and specific for ovarian cancers.

B) INCORRECT:

Anti-HBc immunoglobulin M is a serum marker for acute hepatitis B. While this patient has jaundice and presents with risk factors for hepatitis B infection (travel history, multiple sexual partners, unprotected sex), he does not have other signs of acute viral hepatitis such as fever or tender hepatomegaly. Moreover, in viral hepatitis, jaundice is not cholestatic but results from an acute hepatic dysfunction. Patients would thus present with mixed hyperbilirubinemia rather than just elevated direct bilirubin.

C) INCORRECT:

Perinuclear antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies (p-ANCA) are often found in patients with primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC). Although PSC can manifest with cholestasis, this condition does not cause the double-duct sign seen on imaging. Instead, beading of the extrahepatic and intrahepatic bile ducts would be seen. The jaundice in this patient is best explained by the pancreatic head mass detected on ultrasound.

D) CORRECT:

CA 19-9 is a tumor marker that is elevated in non-malignant hepatobiliary disorders as well as various cancers, most importantly pancreatic adenocarcinoma. Other less sensitive and specific laboratory findings that are elevated in pancreatic cancer include carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA), and, in some cases, lipase levels. Tumor markers should be obtained for disease monitoring rather than for confirmation of the diagnosis. Higher levels of CA 19-9 at initial presentation are associated with a worse prognosis.

E) INCORRECT:

Elevated glucagon levels in the setting of a pancreatic mass are found in patients with glucagonoma. Patients typically present with hyperglycemia, necrolytic migratory erythema, angular cheilitis, and chronic diarrhea. While a glucagonoma can manifest with symptoms that are very similar to pancreatic adenocarcinoma (e.g., weight loss, diarrhea, hyperglycemia, abdominal discomfort), this is a rare neuroendocrine tumor of the pancreas and less likely.

F) INCORRECT:

Alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) levels are most commonly elevated in hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC), ovarian cancer, and mixed germ cell tumors, but AFP-producing pancreatic cancers are very rare and unlikely. Although malignant biliary obstruction is a possible complication of HCC, it is usually a late sign that would typically present with signs of ascites and/or cirrhosis, neither of which are present in this patient. It would also not explain this patient's ultrasound findings.
questions.hint: This patient most likely has a malignant biliary obstruction, as indicated by signs of painless jaundice, pruritus, pale stools, direct hyperbilirubinemia, and elevated alkaline phosphatase. The solitary pancreatic head mass is likely obstructing the biliary and pancreatic ducts and causing subsequent dilation (double duct sign). As a sign of endocrine pancreatic insufficiency, the patient also exhibits elevated serum glucose levels.

questions.text: A 51-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a persistent cough and a 5-kg (11-lb) weight loss over the past 2 months. Yesterday, she coughed up bloody sputum. She does not smoke. Pulmonary examination shows decreased breath sounds over the right upper lobe. A CT scan of the chest shows a mass in the periphery of the right upper lobe. Histopathologic examination of a specimen obtained on CT-guided biopsy shows glandular cells with papillary components and signet ring cells that stain positive for mucin. An activating mutation of which of the following genes is most likely to have occurred in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The BRAF gene is a proto-oncogene, but mutations in BRAF are associated with small cell lung cancer, not non-small cell lung cancers like lung adenocarcinoma. Moreover, these mutations are usually associated with a history of smoking.

B) INCORRECT:

Most types of cancer are associated with mutations in the TP53 gene. However, since TP53 is a tumor suppressor gene rather than a proto-oncogene, there would have to be a loss-of-function mutation rather than an activating mutation for cancer to develop.

C) CORRECT:

Chromosomal translocation of the ALK gene results in the fusion oncogene EML4-ALK, which leads to lung adenocarcinoma. This translocation occurs more frequently in nonsmokers and patients younger than 65 years of age. In addition, signet ring cells are more likely to be seen in lung adenocarcinomas with the EML4-ALK oncogene than those without it. Activating mutations in the EGFR gene and KRAS gene can also cause lung adenocarcinoma. Testing the biopsy specimen for activation of these genes can help predict the efficacy of targeted therapy (e.g., ALK inhibitors, EGFR inhibitors).

See “Overview of proto-oncogenes” table.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a lung tissue sample (H&E stain; 400x magnification)

Several confluent tubular glands lined by atypical epithelium (examples indicated by green outline) and surrounded by desmoplastic hypercellular stroma are visible. There is nuclear stratification (nuclei located at different heights within the epithelium rather than basally only), nuclear hyperchromasia (darker stained nuclei), and pleomorphism (different sizes of cells and nuclei).

These are typical findings in acinar adenocarcinoma of the lung.

D) INCORRECT:

The APC gene is a tumor suppressor gene, not a proto-oncogene. Mutations in the APC gene are associated with colorectal cancer (in particular, familial adenomatous polyposis), not lung adenocarcinoma.

E) INCORRECT:

The SMAD4 (DPC4) gene is a tumor suppressor gene, not a proto-oncogene. Mutations in this gene are associated with the development of pancreatic cancer, not lung adenocarcinoma.

F) INCORRECT:

The MYCL1 gene is a proto-oncogene, but mutations in MYCL1 are associated with about 20% of cases of small cell lung cancer and are not associated with non-small cell lung cancers like lung adenocarcinoma.
questions.hint: This patient has a lung adenocarcinoma, which typically manifests as a glandular tumor in the lung periphery with papillary components and mucin. Activating mutations convert proto-oncogenes into oncogenes.

questions.text: A 31-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of a 4-week history of worsening headache, nausea, and vomiting. The headache is worse at night. Fundoscopic examination shows swelling of the optic discs. A CT scan of the brain shows a heterogeneous, hyperintense, intraventricular mass. The patient undergoes surgical excision of the mass. Pathologic examination of the surgical specimen confirms that the tumor is of neuronal origin. The cells in this specimen are most likely to stain positive for which of the following immunohistochemical markers?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

S-100 is an immunohistochemical marker that identifies cells of neural crest origin. Tumors of neural crest origin that stain positive for S-100 include pheochromocytoma (from chromaffin cells), melanoma, schwannoma, and Langerhans cell histiocytosis.

B) INCORRECT:

Desmin is an immunohistochemical marker that identifies muscle cells. Tumors of muscle cell origin that stain positive for desmin include rhabdomyosarcoma.

C) CORRECT:

Synaptophysin is an immunohistochemical marker that identifies tumors derived from neuronal cells, e.g., neuroendocrine cells, which contain numerous synaptic vesicles. Tumors that stain positive with synaptophysin include neurocytomas, medulloblastomas, small cell carcinomas of the lung, and carcinoid tumors. Neurons also stain positive for neurofilaments, which are part of the neuronal cytoskeleton.

D) INCORRECT:

Glial fibrillary acidic protein (GFAP) is an immunohistochemical marker that identifies cells of glial cell origin, which are non-neuronal cells of the central nervous system. Tumors of glial cell origin that stain positive for GFAP include astrocytoma and glioblastoma.

E) INCORRECT:

Cytokeratin is an immunohistochemical marker that identifies cells of epithelial origin. Tumors of epithelial cell origin that stain positive for cytokeratin include squamous cell carcinoma.
questions.hint: While the vast majority of malignant primary brain tumors in adults derive from glial cells, some brain tumors originate from neuroendocrine cells, which stain positive for a glycoprotein found in neuronal vesicles.

questions.text: A 70-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his wife because of progressive confusion for the past 2 weeks. He has also had a 4.5-kg (10-lb) weight loss and fatigue during the last 6 months. Physical examination shows enlarged lymph nodes in the right axilla and faint expiratory wheezing in the right middle lung field. He is only oriented to person. Serum studies show a sodium concentration of 125 mEq/L and increased antidiuretic hormone concentration. An x-ray of the chest shows a right-sided hilar mass with mediastinal fullness. A biopsy of the hilar mass is most likely to show cells that stain positive for which of the following?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Desmin is a muscle-specific intermediate filament found on immunohistochemical staining of muscle tumors such as rhabdomyosarcoma. This patient has small cell lung cancer, which is not a muscle tumor and does not stain positive for desmin.

B) INCORRECT:

Tartrate-resistant acid phosphatase (TRAP) is an enzyme expressed by dendritic cells, macrophages, and osteoclasts that is found on immunohistochemical staining of hairy cell leukemia. This patient has small cell lung cancer, which does not stain positive for TRAP.

C) INCORRECT:

Neurofilament is a neuron-specific intermediate filament found on immunohistochemical staining of neuronal tumors such as neuroblastoma. This patient has small cell lung cancer, which is not a neuronal tumor and does not stain positive for neurofilament.

D) INCORRECT:

Glial fibrillary acidic protein (GFAP) is a neuroglia-specific intermediate filament found on immunohistochemical staining of glial tumors such as astrocytoma and glioblastoma. This patient has small cell lung cancer, which is not a glial tumor and does not stain positive for GFAP.

E) INCORRECT:

Napsin A is an enzyme found on immunohistochemical staining of several cancers, including lung adenocarcinoma and clear cell endometrial carcinoma. However, it is not expressed by small cell lung cancer. Napsin A staining is used to distinguish lung adenocarcinoma (which typically manifests in the periphery of the lung) from small cell lung cancer (which typically manifests in the central areas of the lung, including the hilar region).

F) INCORRECT:

S-100 is a protein expressed by cells derived from neural crest. Thus, it is found on immunohistochemical staining of tumors derived from these cells, including melanoma, schwannoma, and Langerhans cell histiocytosis. This patient has small cell lung cancer, which does not originate from neural crest cells or stain positive for S-100.

G) INCORRECT:

Vimentin is an intermediate filament that is present in mesenchymal tissue (e.g., cancellous bone, cartilage, muscle, fat, hematopoietic tissues). Thus, it is found on immunohistochemical staining of tumors of mesenchymal origin (sarcomas). Though it is also expressed by several carcinomas (e.g., endometrial carcinoma, renal cell carcinoma), it is not expressed by small cell lung cancer.

H) CORRECT:

Neuron-specific enolase is found on immunohistochemical staining of neuroendocrine tumors such as small cell lung cancer, a neoplasm caused by the proliferation of Kulchitsky cells. Additional immunohistochemical markers for neuroendocrine tumors include chromogranin A and synaptophysin.

Because small cell lung cancer is extremely aggressive and early metastasis is common, surgery is usually not a treatment option. Management typically includes a combination of chemotherapy and radiotherapy.
questions.hint: This patient's hilar mass is caused by small cell lung cancer. This cancer is associated with syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion (SIADH), a paraneoplastic syndrome that causes hyponatremia and subsequent confusion.

questions.text: A 43-year-old man comes to the physician because of weight loss and swelling on the left side of his neck. Physical examination shows a firm, enlarged left upper cervical lymph node that is immobile. Immunohistochemical testing performed on a biopsy specimen from the lymph node stains positive for cytokeratin. Which of the following is the most likely site of the primary neoplasm in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Immunostaining with cytokeratin is positive in epithelial tumors, e.g., basal cell carcinoma or squamous cell carcinoma of the skin. Basal cell carcinoma is the most common type of skin cancer, although it rarely spreads to other organs (e.g., lymph nodes). This patient could have squamous cell carcinoma of the skin, which (in some cases) can spread to regional lymph nodes.

Malignant melanomas arise from neural crest cells and stain positive for the neural crest cell marker S-100.

B) INCORRECT:

The majority of malignant primary brain tumors in adults arise from glial cells of the central nervous system (e.g., glioblastoma multiforme). Metastases from glial cell tumors would stain positive for the glial cell marker glial fibrillary acidic protein (GFAP).

C) INCORRECT:

Peripheral nerve sheath tumors (schwannomas) are composed of Schwann cells, which are derived from neural crest cells. Schwannomas are almost always benign and would stain positive for the neural crest cell marker S-100. Malignant transformation and metastasis to regional lymph nodes rarely occur.

D) INCORRECT:

Sarcomas (e.g., osteosarcoma, Ewing sarcoma, chondrosarcoma) are the most common malignant primary bone tumors and arise from mesenchymal stem cells. Metastases from these tumors would stain positive for the mesenchymal cell marker vimentin.

E) INCORRECT:

Malignant muscle tumors (e.g., rhabdomyosarcoma) are composed of neoplastic myocytes, which contain muscle-specific proteins. Metastases from smooth and skeletal muscle tumors would stain positive for the myocyte cell marker desmin.
questions.hint: Cytokeratin is an intracytoplasmic protein found in cells of epithelial origin.

questions.text: An investigator studying the molecular characteristics of various malignant cell lines collects tissue samples from several families with a known mutation in the TP53 tumor suppressor gene. Immunohistochemical testing performed on one of the cell samples stains positive for desmin. This sample was most likely obtained from which of the following neoplasms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Most prostate cancers are adenocarcinomas, which arise from the glandular tissue of the prostate. Prostate-specific antigen (PSA) levels in both biopsy samples and the blood are used to guide and assess the effectiveness of cancer treatment. However, prostate cancer tissue samples would not be positive for desmin, which is specific to another type of tissue.

B) INCORRECT:

Endometrial carcinoma is mesenchymal in origin and, as such, would stain positive for vimentin, a protein specific to mesenchymal cells that is responsible for maintaining cell shape and cytoplasmic integrity. An endometrial carcinoma tissue sample would not stain positive for desmin, a protein specific to another kind of tissue.

C) INCORRECT:

Squamous cell carcinomas (SCC) can arise from both the skin and the linings of various organs (e.g., lungs, thyroid). However, an SCC tissue sample would stain positive for cytokeratin, a protein specific to epithelial cells that functions to aid in withstanding mechanical stress, rather than desmin, a protein specific to another kind of tissue.

D) INCORRECT:

Melanoma is a type of cancer that develops from melanocytes and stains positive for S-100. S-100 is found in multiple different cell types, including neural crest cells, macrophages, Langerhans cells, and keratinocytes. However, melanoma samples would not stain positive for desmin, which is specific to another type of tissue.

E) INCORRECT:

Carcinoid tumors are neuroendocrine tumors that can arise in a variety of tissues, most commonly in the intestines and lungs, but not in tissues that would stain positive for desmin. Instead, carcinoid tumors stain positive for neuroendocrine markers such as chromogranin A or synaptophysin.

F) CORRECT:

Desmin is an intermediate filament protein of the cytoskeleton of muscle cells. As desmin is specific to muscle, it is only expressed in tumors composed of muscle cells such as rhabdomyosarcomas (striated muscle) or leiomyomas (smooth muscle). Rhabdomyosarcoma is one of the more common malignancies that arise in Li-Fraumeni syndrome. Here, the loss-of-function mutation in a tumor suppressor gene (TP53) results in a loss of heterozygosity and an increased risk for the development of cancer.

See “Overview of immunohistochemical markers” table.

G) INCORRECT:

Glioblastoma is a very aggressive type of brain tumor to which patients with Li-Fraumeni syndrome have an increased familial disposition. The exact cell line origin of glioblastoma remains unclear. However, glioblastoma has been linked to glial fibrillary acidic protein (GFAP), for which its cells would stain positive. However, glioblastoma tissue samples would not stain positive for desmin, which is specific to another tissue type.
questions.hint: A hereditary mutation in TP53 is seen in Li-Fraumeni syndrome. This condition is associated with various malignancies that occur at an early age, one of which arises in a type of tissue that routinely expresses desmin, a type of intermediate filament.

questions.text:
A 27-year-old man presents with a right testicular mass that has been growing for the past several months. He denies pain, dysuria, sexual dysfunction, or a history of sex without condoms. He underwent orchiopexy in his late teens for congenital cryptorchidism on the right side.
On physical examination, palpation of the scrotum reveals a hard, 8-mm mass in the upper pole of the right testicle. There is no inguinal lymphadenopathy. The remainder of the physical examination is normal.
An ultrasound of the testicle confirms the presence of the suspicious mass.
Which one of the following tumor markers is most likely to be elevated in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Carbohydrate antigen 19-9 (CA 19-9) is not considered to be useful in patients with testicular tumors. CA 19-9 is used primarily in pancreatic cancer.

B) INCORRECT:

Carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA) is not considered to be useful in patients with testicular tumors. CEA is elevated in certain gastrointestinal tumors, some lung and breast cancers, and some cases of medullary thyroid cancer.

C) CORRECT:

Testicular tumors are the most common malignant tumors in young men. Most palpable testicular tumors in adults are malignant. Men with a history of cryptorchidism have an increased risk for the development of cancer in either testicle. The majority of testicular cancers in cryptorchid testicles are pure seminomas.

Human chorionic gonadotropin is a tumor marker that is typically elevated in patients with seminoma. It is thought to correlate more to the presence of trophoblast cells within the tumor than to the stage of the tumor.

Serum alpha-fetoprotein is only rarely elevated in patients with pure seminomas and, when detectable, is present only at low levels.

Orchiopexy before puberty reduces the risk for testicular cancer to a greater extent than orchiopexy after puberty. Orchiopexy is not necessary immediately after birth, because about half of cryptorchid testicles will descend spontaneously within the first 6 months of life.

Key learning point: The tumor marker most likely to be elevated in a young man with corrected cryptorchidism who presents with a suspicious testicular mass is human chorionic gonadotropin.

D) INCORRECT:

Cancer antigen 125 (CA-125) is not considered to be useful in patients with testicular tumors. CA-125 can be used as a tumor marker in women with ovarian cancer.

E) INCORRECT:

The majority of testicular cancers in cryptorchid testicles are pure seminomas. Serum alpha-fetoprotein is only rarely elevated in patients with pure seminomas and, when detectable, is present only at low levels.

questions.text: A previously healthy 48-year-old man comes to the office because of a 3-week history of progressively worsening jaundice, generalized itching, and epigastric discomfort. His stools have looked like clay for the past week. Examination shows superficial excoriations on all limbs. Serum studies show an elevated fasting glucose level, direct bilirubin concentration, and alkaline phosphatase activity. Abdominal ultrasonography shows dilation of the biliary and pancreatic ducts and a 3-cm hypoechoic solid mass with irregular margins in the head of the pancreas. An elevation of which of the following serum findings is most specific for this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Anti-HBc immunoglobulin M is a serum marker for acute hepatitis B. While this patient has jaundice, he does not have other signs of acute viral hepatitis such as fever or tender hepatomegaly. Moreover, in viral hepatitis, jaundice is not cholestatic but results from an acute hepatic dysfunction. Patients would thus present with mixed hyperbilirubinemia rather than just elevated direct bilirubin.

B) INCORRECT:

Perinuclear antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies (p-ANCA) are often found in patients with primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC). Although PSC can manifest with cholestasis, this condition does not cause the double-duct sign seen on imaging. Instead, beading of the extrahepatic and intrahepatic bile ducts would be seen. The jaundice in this patient is best explained by the pancreatic head mass detected on ultrasound.

C) CORRECT:

CA 19-9 is a tumor marker that is elevated in non-malignant hepatobiliary disorders as well as various cancers, most importantly pancreatic adenocarcinoma. Other less sensitive and specific laboratory findings that are elevated in pancreatic cancer include carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA), and, in some cases, lipase levels. Tumor markers should be obtained for disease monitoring rather than for confirmation of the diagnosis. Higher levels of CA 19-9 at initial presentation are associated with a worse prognosis.

Key learning point: Cancer antigen 19-9 is the most specific serum marker for pancreatic adenocarcinoma causing malignant biliary obstruction.

D) INCORRECT:

Elevated glucagon levels in the setting of a pancreatic mass are found in patients with glucagonoma. Patients typically present with hyperglycemia, necrolytic migratory erythema, angular cheilitis, and chronic diarrhea. While a glucagonoma can manifest with symptoms that are very similar to pancreatic adenocarcinoma (e.g., weight loss, diarrhea, hyperglycemia, abdominal discomfort), this is a rare neuroendocrine tumor of the pancreas and less likely.

E) INCORRECT:

Alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) levels are most commonly elevated in hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC), ovarian cancer, and mixed germ cell tumors, but AFP-producing pancreatic cancers are very rare and unlikely. Although malignant biliary obstruction is a possible complication of HCC, it is usually a late sign that would typically present with signs of ascites and/or cirrhosis, neither of which are present in this patient. It would also not explain this patient's ultrasound findings.
questions.hint: This patient most likely has a malignant biliary obstruction, as indicated by signs of painless jaundice, pruritus, pale stools, direct hyperbilirubinemia, and elevated alkaline phosphatase. The solitary pancreatic head mass is likely obstructing the biliary and pancreatic ducts and causing subsequent dilation (double duct sign). As a sign of endocrine pancreatic insufficiency, the patient also exhibits elevated serum glucose levels.

questions.text: A previously healthy 48-year-old man comes to your clinic with a 3-week history of progressively worsening jaundice, generalized pruritus, and epigastric discomfort. He reports that his stools have appeared clay-colored for the past week. On examination, there are superficial excoriations on all limbs. Serum studies reveal elevated fasting glucose, direct bilirubin, and alkaline phosphatase. Abdominal ultrasonography shows dilation of the biliary and pancreatic ducts and a 3-cm hypoechoic solid mass with irregular margins in the head of the pancreas. Which one of the following serum findings, if elevated, is most specific for this condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Elevated glucagon levels in the setting of a pancreatic mass are found in patients with glucagonoma. Patients typically present with hyperglycemia, necrolytic migratory erythema, angular cheilitis, and chronic diarrhea. While a glucagonoma can manifest with symptoms that are very similar to pancreatic adenocarcinoma (e.g., weight loss, diarrhea, hyperglycemia, abdominal discomfort), this is a rare neuroendocrine tumor of the pancreas and less likely.

B) CORRECT:

CA 19-9 is a tumor marker that is elevated in non-malignant hepatobiliary disorders as well as various cancers, most importantly pancreatic adenocarcinoma. Other less sensitive and specific laboratory findings that are elevated in pancreatic cancer include carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA), and, in some cases, lipase levels. Tumor markers should be obtained for disease monitoring rather than for confirmation of the diagnosis. Higher levels of CA 19-9 at initial presentation are associated with a worse prognosis.

Key learning point: Cancer antigen 19-9 (CA 19-9) is the most specific serum marker for pancreatic adenocarcinoma causing malignant biliary obstruction.

C) INCORRECT:

Alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) levels are most commonly elevated in hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC), ovarian cancer, and mixed germ cell tumors, but AFP-producing pancreatic cancers are very rare and unlikely. Although malignant biliary obstruction is a possible complication of HCC, it is usually a late sign that would typically present with signs of ascites and/or cirrhosis, neither of which are present in this patient. It would also not explain this patient's ultrasound findings.

D) INCORRECT:

Anti-HBc immunoglobulin M is a serum marker for acute hepatitis B. While this patient has jaundice, he does not have other signs of acute viral hepatitis such as fever or tender hepatomegaly. Moreover, in viral hepatitis, jaundice is not cholestatic but results from an acute hepatic dysfunction. Patients would thus present with mixed hyperbilirubinemia rather than just elevated direct bilirubin.

E) INCORRECT:

Perinuclear antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies (p-ANCA) are often found in patients with primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC). Although PSC can manifest with cholestasis, this condition does not cause the double-duct sign seen on imaging. Instead, beading of the extrahepatic and intrahepatic bile ducts would be seen. The jaundice in this patient is best explained by the pancreatic head mass detected on ultrasound.
questions.hint: This patient most likely has a malignant biliary obstruction, as indicated by signs of painless jaundice, pruritus, pale stools, direct hyperbilirubinemia, and elevated alkaline phosphatase. The solitary pancreatic head mass is likely obstructing the biliary and pancreatic ducts and causing subsequent dilation (double duct sign). As a sign of endocrine pancreatic insufficiency, the patient also exhibits elevated serum glucose levels.
